name: Sales Rep Forwarded Customer Email - Dialysis Machine
description: Sales representative forwarding customer complaint email chain about dialysis machine issue. Contains original customer email plus sales rep context.

headers.subject: FW: URGENT - Dialysis machine alarm issue - Midwest Kidney Center

raw_input.body:
Team,

Forwarding this from my customer at Midwest Kidney Center. This is a large account (12 machines) and they're very concerned. The biomedical engineer is solid - if he says there's an issue, there is.

I've already contacted them to get more details. They have documented 3 separate incidents over the past week with the same model. No patients harmed yet but this sounds serious.

Please advise how I should respond and whether we need to escalate.

Thanks,
Mike Chen
Senior Sales Representative - Midwest Region
RenalCare Devices
(555) 333-2211

-------- Original Message --------
From: Tom Williams <t.williams@midwestkidney.org>
Sent: Friday, April 12, 2024 4:47 PM
To: mike.chen@renalcare-devices.com
Subject: URGENT - Dialysis machine alarm issue

Mike,

We have a serious problem with three of our RenalCare Hemodialysis System 5000 units.

Over the past week, we've had 3 incidents where the air detector alarm failed to activate during treatment. In each case, our nurses caught the air in the line visually during routine monitoring. If they hadn't been paying close attention, air could have been infused into patients.

The affected units are:
- S/N RCH5K-2023-11234 (Treatment room 3)
- S/N RCH5K-2023-11235 (Treatment room 5)  
- S/N RCH5K-2023-11238 (Treatment room 8)

All three were installed in September 2023 from the same shipment.

I've taken all three units offline and we're using backup equipment. We need someone here ASAP to investigate. Our clinical director is very concerned and is considering whether we need to report this to the FDA ourselves.

Please call me first thing Monday.

Tom Williams
Director of Biomedical Engineering
Midwest Kidney Center
(555) 444-5566

event_info.event_description: Air detector alarm failed to activate during hemodialysis treatment on 3 separate units from the same shipment. Air in line was caught by nurses during visual monitoring in each case. Potential for air embolism if not detected.
event_info.patient_outcome: No patient harm - air detected visually by nursing staff
event_info.device_outcome: All 3 affected units taken offline, backup equipment in use

expected_complaint.narrative: Three RenalCare Hemodialysis System 5000 units at Midwest Kidney Center had air detector alarm failures during treatment over the past week. In each incident, nurses caught air in the line during visual monitoring. Serial numbers: RCH5K-2023-11234, RCH5K-2023-11235, RCH5K-2023-11238. All units from same September 2023 shipment. Units taken offline. Potential for air embolism if not detected. Originally reported by biomedical engineering director to sales rep, who forwarded to complaints team.

ground_truth.coding_rationale: A02 (Device Operates Differently Than Expected) for alarm failure. A15 (Failure to Operate) for alarm system failure. C10 (No Patient Problem) as no harm occurred. MDR required because air embolism from undetected air in line could cause death. Multiple units affected increases urgency.

extraction_challenges: Original reporter info in forwarded email
Context added by sales rep separate from original complaint
notes: Critical safety issue - air detector failure on dialysis equipment. Multiple units from same batch suggests potential lot issue. Near-miss scenario with high potential severity.
